verb.description: Kill or wound (a person or animal) with a bullet or arrow.
examples: he was shot in the leg during an armed robbery

verb.description: Move suddenly and rapidly in a particular direction.
examples: Ward's hand shot out, grabbing his arm

verb.description: (in soccer, hockey, basketball, etc.) kick, hit, or throw the ball or puck in an attempt to score a goal.
examples: after school, we'd go straight out in the alley to shoot baskets

verb.description: Film or photograph (a scene, film, etc.)
examples: she has just been commissioned to shoot a video
point the camera and just shoot—nothing could be easier

verb.description: (of a plant or seed) send out buds or shoots; germinate.
Inject oneself or another person with (a narcotic drug)
examples: he shot dope into his arm

verb.description: Plane (the edge of a board) accurately.

noun.description: A young branch or sucker springing from the main stock of a tree or other plant.
examples: he nipped off the new shoots that grew where the leaves joined the stems

noun.description: An occasion when a group of people hunt and shoot game for sport.
An occasion when a professional photographer takes photographs or when a film or video is being made.

examples: follow the portages that skirt all nine shoots of whitewater

exclamation.description: Used as a euphemism for shit
examples: shoot, it was a great day to be alive

phrases: Firstly, these kids were attending Sandringham Church, not shooting the breeze in some Internet chat room or hanging round a bus-stop and smoking.
Jon and I would just sit in the tent with the microphone between us and start shooting the breeze, says Liesl Clark.
We were just two unemployed guys who once worked together - shooting the breeze, telling war stories.
Last I heard, Bellows was heading out to New York to help start a new magazine, while still shooting the bull about creating a newspaper in Los Angeles.
Above the thunderous whir of the aircraft rotors, Nelson and his buddies yelled back and forth, shooting the bull as the copter lifted off.
their helicopter was shot down by an air-to-air missile
As often happens at critical moments, unanticipated circumstances interfered with shooting the aircraft down during the Central Asian leg of its overflight of the USSR.
During one attack a Scud missile was shot down overhead and the wreckage was left in his camp for three days.
As the summer progresses and multiple German attacks arrive every day, many German planes are shot down, but British losses of planes and particularly pilots become critical.
I know probably how these individuals felt to some extent before they were shot down and lost their lives.
origin: Old English scēotan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch schieten and German schiessen, also to sheet, shot, and shut.
